_header: Edward the Third that was king of this land
Note:
Ringler Jr. (1988)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse Printed 1476-1558. London: Mansell, 1988, TP 362.5; for later continuations see 6694 and 3658; cf. also Kingsford (1912)
XKingsford, Charles Lethbridge. “The First Version of Hardyng’s Chronicle.” English Historical Review 27 (1912): 740-53 462-82.
Bibliographic Ghosts: Oxford, All Souls College 33: see 952; London, British Library Harley 293: only prose in this section of the MS
_description: John Hardyng, Metrical Chronicle, generally with a dedication to Henry VI; some MSS with concluding Envoy to Edward IV, and other end-matter.

BodAsh34.First Lines:
The most substaunce of power and of myghtThurgh age destelled in to
                    debelyteOf me that am this tyme an age wightAnd grete faulte have of
                    abelyte
BodAsh34.Last Lines:
…For langer þan ye have hem in subIeccyounTrest never
                    truthe in hem ne perfeccyoun

Ends with the 240th chapter of Grafton’s edition
                    (1543).

BodDou345.First Lines:
The moost substaunce of Power and of mightThorough age distilled in
                    to debilite…
BodDou345.Last Lines:
…At ouer þe flok to seke the Scatred schepeAnd laye hem
                    in your fold surely to slepe

BLCottVesAXII.First Lines: Staumford he made so callyd to thys dayIn whych he made a vniuersite…
BLCottVesAXII.Last Lines: …In all the vii liberall scienceffor to purchese wysdam & sapience
BLCottVesAXII.Note: Fragment (written in verse lines) inserted in a Latin prose chronicle.

BLEge1992.First Lines:
[T]he most substance of power and of myghtThurgh age distilled into
                    debilite…
BLEge1992.Last Lines:
…To bide euer more vndere his protecconWherfor gode lorde nowe
                    girde you with your swerde
BLEge1992.Note:
Ends imperfectly. Space left for enlarged initial ‘T’, which
                    was left blank.

BLHar661.First Lines:
Which…after of Marche and of VlsterWith…slayne wase in
                    grelonde…
BLHar661.Last Lines:
…That youre highnes may haue therof knowlageTo comfort with
                    youre noble high corage
BLHar661.Note:
Abbreviated version for Edward IV, 1800 stanzas. Begins imperfectly due
                    to loss of leaves and damage to tops of leaves at beginning of codex; last few
                    stanzas intermingled with lists of distances between stops on the route to
                    Scotland, which continue with prose directions on ff. 185-186, followed by
                    maps.

BLHar3730.First Lines: As cronicles be fore haue made memorieEnglond and walles as to thaire soffrayne…
BLHar3730.Last Lines: …that ȝoure highe highnes þer off may haue knowlegesTo conforte ȝoure highe noble corage
BLHar3730.Note: Verses from Epilogue only. In penultimate line “highe” written and expunged before “highnes.”

BLLan204.First Lines:
The while that Troy was regnyng in his myghtThere was in grece a
                    kinge right excellent…
BLLan204.Last Lines:
…As Bretons had of grete antiquyteWhan they it helde in myghty
                    dignyte
BLLan204.Note:
2700 stanzas. Full-page illustrations on fols. 196 and
                    226v-227.
BLLan204.Editions:
Kingsford,  Charles Lethbridge. 
             “The First Version of Hardyng’s Chronicle.” 
             English Historical Review
         27 (1912): 740-53: 740-53 (extracts only).

GULHun400.First Lines:
eDward the iiide that was kyng of this londBe iuste
                    title and verray rygh descent…
GULHun400.Last Lines:
…Thre myle be west ye may Passe ouer forth Into Menteth that
                    lieth there by north
GULHun400.Note:
Regular verse ends f. 180v, ‘That your highnesse may
                    have therof knowlege / To comforte with your noble high corage’; followed
                    by directions on the way to Edinburgh, and on the way from Edinburgh to
                    Stirling, including two rhyme royal stanzas, both f. 181v, beginning,
                    ‘And your wille and noble high corage / Thinketh this is ouer sitill to
                    your puissaunce…’.
GULHun400.Attributed Author: The prolog of John Hardyng maker of this boke (f. 1)

PULGar142.First Lines:
The most substaunce of power and of myȝtÞurgh age
                    distilled in debiliteOf me þat am þis tyme an aged wightAnd
                    grete defaute have of abilitie…
PULGar142.Last Lines:
…Than was he made knyȝt of þe GartierAt his desire
                    as saith the Cronycler…
PULGar142.Note:
With prologue by the ‘maker of þis booke’ (ff.
                        21-23v); first line of text begins, ‘As Cronicles telle
                    & make notificacioun / Ho so payn wele shal know &
                    vnderstond…’ (f. 23v); ends in reign of Henry V, with
                    catchwords indicating once continued.
PULGar142.Attributed Title:
Hire begynneth þe boke of Brytoun of what blode Brute came & howe
                    he gate þis Ile & named hit Britayn þat nowe is Englond Wales
                    & Scotlond (f. 23v)
